comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: An educated guess - Peat Island c.1911, when a psychiatric hospital was established? - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peat_Island . There is a stone circle at the southern end of the island which might have been the foundation of this charming summer house. Google satellite - maps.google.com.au/maps?ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=Sydney+...

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I think you're right. I just uploaded this photo of Peat Island www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4841767519/ Same turret?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: That has to be the same building ( www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4841767519/ ). But I was wrong; it used to be on the NW tip of Peat Island, where the large round water tower now is. This makes sense of the lack of window shutters on the east windows. It looks like the same characters are in both photos, particularly the gent with pale trousers and a cane (Fred Astaire?!).

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Looks to be a slight resemblance!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: More about Peat Island - scratchingsydneyssurface.wordpress.com/2010/03/04/5-march... , including details of a recent book. I wonder if that building is the 'sewing room' mentioned? " The smaller of the two islands, which was Peat Island (earlier known as Rabbit Island), was to be for women. In a major engineering work, the island was cleared of vegetation and levelled to bedrock. Two ward buildings, a kitchen and sewing room were erected between 1902 and 1904. "

comment.author: 54456898@N00
comment._content: This photograph is of an official visit to Peat Island (then known as Rabbit Island) in 1904 - the hexagonal building is the original sewing room, which was later relocated to the opposite end of the island. This photograph (and three others) are also held at the State Library of NSW: acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=64621

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/Rabbitfoot] Thanks for your info and research! We have amended the caption and will also update Photo Investigator.

comment.author: 54456898@N00
comment._content: Great! Spelling is sewing (not sowing) though...

comment.author: 90730890@N05
comment._content: My Nan was the first Female to work on Rabbit Island. Her name was Patricia Ross and is now Patricia Schembri.
